I am able to run multiple instances of a single JUnit class to test
projects.  In order to do this, the JUnit class runs an instance of a
program and determines whether it passes or fails.  Only one class is
needed because I can pass different projects and achieve the results. 
Creating multiple classes in this case is wasteful because all the
same code would be reused with the exception of the name of the
class.  However, because only a single class is used, the JUnit
report  option when running ANT cannot determine the difference
between runs - it only knows it is another run of the same class.

How could I utilize the built in capabilities for reporting with only
that single class?   I am not familiar with what information is picked
up upon compilation of the report.  Perhaps there is a way to "fool"
the software into thinking they are actually separate classes since
they are completely separate tests that I've had create their own
separate XML output.  I am attempting to be platform independent,
however, I may need to implement modifications with a shell script and
later duplicate similar actions in a batch script for windows.

In general, the output shows that there were a certain number of
tests, but because the same class is used, the <class>.html file is
overwritten along with other helpful output information.  This leaves
only the output for the last test run.

If anyone knows a good method for getting around this JUnit
limitation, please let me know!!!

David
